assemblage.title: Slope-Intercept Form
assemblage.p: If we write the equation of a linear function in the form, f (x) = b + mx then m is the slopeslope of the line, and b is the y-intercept.

statement.p: The temperature inside a pottery drying oven starts at 70 degrees and is rising at a rate of 0.5 degrees per minute. Write a function for the temperature, H, inside the oven after t minutes.

solution.p: At t=0, the temperature is 70 degrees, so b=70. The slope is given by the rate of increase of H, so m=0.5. Thus, the function is H=70+0.5t.

statement.p: A perfect score on a driving test is 120 points, and you lose 4 points for each wrong answer. Write a function for your score, S, if you give n wrong answers.

solution.p: If n=0, your score is 120, so b=120. Your score decreases by 4 points per wrong answer, so m=\dfrac{\Delta S}{\Delta n} = 4. The function is S=120-4n.

statement.p: Monica has saved $7800 to live on while she attends college. She spends $600 a month. Write a function for the amount, S, in Monica's savings account after t months.

Jesse opened a new doughnut shop in an old store-front. He invested $2400 in remodeling and set-up, and he makes about $400 per week from the business. Write a function giving the shop's financial standing, F, after w weeks.

assemblage.title: Point-Slope Formula
assemblage.p: To find an equation for the line of slope m passing through the point (x_1,y_1), use the point-slope formula \dfrac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} = m or y-y_1=m(x-x_1)

statement.p: Find an equation for the line that passes through (1,3) and has slope -2.

solution.p: We substitute x_1=\alert{1}, y_1=\alert{3}, and m=\alert{-2} into the point-slope formula. \begin{aligned}[t] y-\alert{3} \amp = \alert{-2} (x-\alert{1}) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}}\\ y-3 \amp = -2x + 2 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Add 3 to both sides.}}\\ y \amp = -2x + 5 \amp \amp \end{aligned}

statement.p: Find an equation for the line of slope \dfrac{-1}{2} that passes through (-3,-2).

solution.p: We substitute x_1=\alert{-3}, y_1=\alert{-2}, and m=\alert{\dfrac{-1}{2}} into the point-slope formula. \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{y-(\alert{-2})}{x-(\alert{-3})} \amp = \alert{\dfrac{-1}{2}} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Simplify the left side.}}\\ \dfrac{y+2}{x+3} \amp = \dfrac{-1}{2} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Cross-multiply.}}\\ 2(y+2) \amp = -1(x+3) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}}\\ 2y+4 \amp = -x-3 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Subtract 4 from both sides.}}\\ 2y \amp = -x-7 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 2.}}\\ y \amp = \dfrac{-1}{2}x-\dfrac{7}{2} \amp \amp \end{aligned}

statement.p: Find an equation for the line of slope -4 that passes through (2,-5).
Find an equation for the line of slope \dfrac{2}{3} that passes through (-6,1).

stack.p: Begin by plotting the y-intercept, (0,-2). We use the slope, \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{3}{4}, to find another point on the line, as follows. Start at the point (0,-2) and move 3 units up and 4 units to the right. Plot a second point here, at (4,1).

Find a third point by writing the slope as \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{-3}{-4}: from (0,-2), move down 3 units and 4 units to the left. Plot a third point here, at (-4,-5). Finally, draw a line through the three points.

statement.p: Graph the line of slope \dfrac{-1}{2} that passes through (-3,-2).

stack.p: Begin by plotting the point (-3,-2). Use the slope, \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{-1}{2}, to find another point on the line, as follows. Start at the point (-3,-2) and move 1 unit down and 3 units to the right. Plot a second point here, at (-1,-31).

Find a third point by writing the slope as \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{1}{-2}: from (-3,-2), move 1 unit up and 2 units to the left. Plot a third point here, at (-5,-1). Finally, draw a line through the three points.
